content:
Let us assume we know of two morphisms s,r:A→Bs,r: A \to Bs,r:A→B, in a category C\mathsf{C}C that has binary products. In this setting, there are some morphisms to B×BB \times BB×B from AAA that must exist, because of the fact that B×BB \times BB×B is a product. How many of these are there?

For a specific example, in the category of sets, consider s,r:R→Rs,r: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}s,r:R→R with s(x)=2xs(x) = 2xs(x)=2x and r(x)=x2r(x) = x^2r(x)=x2 for each x∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R. Then we get four functions from R\mathbb{R}R to R×R\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}R×R. Namely, the ones that act like this: x↦(2x,2x)x \mapsto (2x, 2x)x↦(2x,2x), x↦(x2,x2)x \mapsto (x^2, x^2)x↦(x2,x2), x↦(2x,x2)x \mapsto (2x, x^2)x↦(2x,x2), and x↦(x2,2x)x \mapsto (x^2, 2x)x↦(x2,2x).

morphism to product

Returning to the category C\mathsf{C}C, we have a function !:C(A,B)×C(A,B)→C(A,B×B)!: \mathsf{C}(A,B) \times \mathsf{C}(A,B) \to \mathsf{C}(A, B \times B)!:C(A,B)×C(A,B)→C(A,B×B) where C(A,B)\mathsf{C}(A,B)C(A,B) denotes the set of morphisms from AAA to BBB (so I am assuming C\mathsf{C}C is locally small). As illustrated in the "morphism to product" figure, this function takes in two morphisms from AAA to BBB, and provides the unique morphism that makes the above diagram commute (and such a morphism exists and is unique because B×BB \times BB×B together with π1\pi_1π1​ and π2\pi_2π2​ is a product of BBB and BBB).

If we start with two morphisms from AAA to BBB, do we always get four distinct morphisms from AAA to B×BB \times BB×B using !!!, as we did in the example above in the category of sets? More generally, I'm wondering if the function !!! is injective, so that we always get different morphisms from AAA to B×BB \times BB×B when we specify different pairs of morphisms from AAA to BBB.
The universal property of the product says precisely that this function !!! is a bijection.

Ralph Sarkis said:

The universal property of the product says precisely that this function !!! is a bijection.

(so in particular, it is injective, just to spell it out)
I thought I knew what a "universal property" was, but apparently I do not! Thank-you for pointing me in the right direction. It looks like this nlab page will be helpful.
I will see if I can figure this out based on this hint :smile: .
If you like to understand things from a more general/abstract point of view, you can try to prove that the Hom functors are continuous (the proof on the nlab can seem a bit opaque).

Here's a common shorthand way of stating the universal property for product:

"A morphism from A to X ×\times× Y is the same as a morphism from A to X and and morphism from A to Y."

This is shorthand for saying there's a natural isomorphism

C(A,X×Y)≅C(A,X)×C(A,Z)\mathsf{C}(A,X \times Y) \cong \mathsf{C}(A,X) \times \mathsf{C}(A,Z) C(A,X×Y)≅C(A,X)×C(A,Z)

And that, in turn, is shorthand for stating how the product has a universal property such that for any pair of morphisms f:A→Xf: A \to Xf:A→X, g:A→Yg: A \to Yg:A→Y, there exists a unique morphism f:A→X×Yf: A \to X \times Yf:A→X×Y such that... blah-di-blah-di-blah.
The "blah-di-blah-di-blah" is important but we often don't want to say it all, so we often use these shorter formulations.
The shorter formulations are weaker, in that they follow from the precise one. But you have to do a little work to see why!
Also, to understand the first, shortest formulation I gave, you need to understand what category theorists mean by "the same as". It doesn't always mean "equal"!
In this case it means there's a natural bijection.

Thanks for your responses! I'm currently working on wrapping my head around how we get from a universal property (in terms of representability of a functor) to a limit/colimit description of a representing object. I'll try to answer my question above using this once I get a bit further in understanding this.

This thread has been great - I've wanted to understand some of this stuff for a while, and having a specific example has been really helpful.

I think I now understand the following example: in the category of sets, if there exists some object ZZZ so that Set(−,Z)≅Set(−,A)×Set(−,B)\mathsf{Set}(-,Z) \cong \mathsf{Set}(-,A) \times \mathsf{Set}(-,B)Set(−,Z)≅Set(−,A)×Set(−,B) then ZZZ is forced to satisfy the diagram that means it is a product of AAA and BBB. So if Set(−,Z)≅Set(−,A)×Set(−,B)\mathsf{Set}(-,Z) \cong \mathsf{Set}(-,A) \times \mathsf{Set}(-,B)Set(−,Z)≅Set(−,A)×Set(−,B) then Z≅A×BZ \cong A \times BZ≅A×B. It was very cool to see how this is required by starting with the natural isomorphism diagram between Set(−,Z)\mathsf{Set}(-,Z)Set(−,Z) and Set(−,A)×Set(−,B)\mathsf{Set}(-,A) \times \mathsf{Set}(-,B)Set(−,A)×Set(−,B).

However, I think what I'm asking in this thread actually involves going in the other direction: In a category C\mathsf{C}C, if Z≅A×B\mathsf{Z} \cong A \times BZ≅A×B, then is C(−,Z)≅C(−,A)×C(−,B)\mathsf{C}(-,Z) \cong \mathsf{C}(-,A) \times \mathsf{C}(-,B)C(−,Z)≅C(−,A)×C(−,B)?
Maybe now that I have a little practice with related ideas, I can figure out how to construct a natural isomorphism from the fact that ZZZ is a product.

David Egolf said:

However, I think what I'm asking in this thread actually involves going in the other direction: In a category C\mathsf{C}C, if Z≅A×B\mathsf{Z} \cong A \times BZ≅A×B, then is C(−,Z)≅C(−,A)×C(−,B)\mathsf{C}(-,Z) \cong \mathsf{C}(-,A) \times \mathsf{C}(-,B)C(−,Z)≅C(−,A)×C(−,B)?

This is true, and it feels easier to me than the implication in the other direction!

The reason is that if Z≅A×BZ \cong A \times BZ≅A×B I can use the definition of A×BA \times BA×B to get a morphism from XXX to ZZZ from a pair of morphisms X→AX \to AX→A, X→BX \to BX→B, and also vice versa. This is what the universal property definition of A×BA \times BA×B does.

So we just need to check that the resulting bijection C(X,Z)≅C(X,A)×C(X,B)\mathsf{C}(X,Z) \cong \mathsf{C}(X,A) \times \mathsf{C}(X,B)C(X,Z)≅C(X,A)×C(X,B) is actually natural, and that feels like a "follow your nose" argument.

John Baez said:

The reason is that if Z≅Z×BZ \cong Z \times BZ≅Z×B I can use the definition of A×BA \times BA×B to get a morphism from XXX to ZZZ from a pair of morphisms X→ZX \to ZX→Z, Y→ZY \to ZY→Z, and also vice versa. This is what the universal property definition of A×BA \times BA×B does.

I think there is at least one typo here, and I'm getting confused staring at this. I'm pretty sure you mean to start by assuming that Z≅A×BZ \cong A \times BZ≅A×B, unless I'm missing something?

John Baez said:

So we just need to check that the resulting bijection C(X,Z)≅C(X,A)×C(X,B)\mathsf{C}(X,Z) \cong \mathsf{C}(X,A) \times \mathsf{C}(X,B)C(X,Z)≅C(X,A)×C(X,B) is actually natural, and that feels like a "follow your nose" argument.

I'm a bit stuck on showing that there is a bijection at all. Here's what I've got so far:
If ZZZ is a product of AAA and BBB we have this diagram:
product

Given a choice of an object XXX in C\mathsf{C}C, then because ZZZ together with π1\pi_1π1​ and π2\pi_2π2​ is a product of AAA and BBB, for each pair (f1,f2)(f_1, f_2)(f1​,f2​) there is a unique morphism !(f1,f2)!(f_1, f_2)!(f1​,f2​) that makes this diagram commute. So, given a pair of morphisms in C(X,A)×C(X,B)\mathsf{C}(X,A) \times \mathsf{C}(X,B)C(X,A)×C(X,B) we get a unique morphism in C(X,Z)\mathsf{C}(X,Z)C(X,Z) that makes this diagram commute. That means that !!! is a function from C(X,A)×C(X,B)\mathsf{C}(X,A) \times \mathsf{C}(X,B)C(X,A)×C(X,B) to C(X,Z)\mathsf{C}(X,Z)C(X,Z). We want to show this function is a bijection.

For any h∈C(X,Z)h \in \mathsf{C}(X,Z)h∈C(X,Z), we can compose with π1\pi_1π1​ and π2\pi_2π2​ to get π1∘h∈C(X,A)\pi_1 \circ h \in \mathsf{C}(X,A)π1​∘h∈C(X,A) and π2∘h∈C(X,B)\pi_2 \circ h \in \mathsf{C}(X,B)π2​∘h∈C(X,B). If we set f1f_1f1​ and f2f_2f2​ to be these composed morphisms, then the diagram commutes.
So, for any h∈C(X,Z)h \in \mathsf{C}(X,Z)h∈C(X,Z) there is an element g=(π1∘h,π2∘h)∈C(X,A)×C(X,B)g = (\pi_1 \circ h, \pi_2 \circ h) \in \mathsf{C}(X,A) \times \mathsf{C}(X,B)g=(π1​∘h,π2​∘h)∈C(X,A)×C(X,B) so that !(g)=h!(g) = h!(g)=h. That means that !!! is a surjective function.

It remains to show that !!! is an injective function, and that is where I'm stuck.
If both !(f1,f2)=!(g1,g2)!(f_1,f_2) = {!}(g_1,g_2)!(f1​,f2​)=!(g1​,g2​), then !(g1,g2)!(g_1,g_2)!(g1​,g2​) makes the diagram above commute, so you can find what g1g_1g1​ and g2g_2g2​ are.

David Egolf said:

John Baez said:

The reason is that if Z≅Z×BZ \cong Z \times BZ≅Z×B I can use the definition of A×BA \times BA×B to get a morphism from XXX to ZZZ from a pair of morphisms X→ZX \to ZX→Z, Y→ZY \to ZY→Z, and also vice versa. This is what the universal property definition of A×BA \times BA×B does.

I think there is at least one typo here, and I'm getting confused staring at this. I'm pretty sure you mean to start by assuming that Z≅A×BZ \cong A \times BZ≅A×B, unless I'm missing something?

Ugh, yes there are lots of typos there.

But please read what I mean, not what I wrote! :upside_down:

I meant:

The reason is that if Z≅A×BZ \cong A \times BZ≅A×B I can use the definition of A×BA \times BA×B to get a morphism from XXX to ZZZ from a pair of morphisms X→AX \to AX→A, X→BX \to BX→B, and also vice versa. This is what the universal property definition of A×BA \times BA×B does.

It remains to show that !!! is an injective function, and that is where I'm stuck.

There are always two ways to attempt to show a function is bijective: the noble way and the ignoble way. The noble way is to construct an inverse. The ignoble way is to show it's injective and surjective. I recommend always starting with the noble way, and resorting to the ignoble way only if the noble way fails.
The noble way is noble because it's a general fact about categories that "an isomorphism is a morphism with an inverse".
The ignoble way is ignoble because it's a very special fact about the category Set that "an isomorphism is an epimorphism that's also a monomorphism". This fails in most categories.
So, it's kind of shocking to me that you first tried the ignoble way.
This is probably because instead of "isomorphism" you were saying "bijection", and thinking "one-to-one and onto".
Here's another way to see why the noble way is nicer: it's simpler!

Compare:

A function f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y is an isomorphism if there's a function g:Y→Xg: Y \to Xg:Y→X such that fg=1fg = 1fg=1 and gf=1gf = 1gf=1

to

A function f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y is an isomorphism if for every y∈Yy \in Yy∈Y there exists x∈Xx \in Xx∈X such that f(x)=yf(x) = yf(x)=y and for every x,x′∈Xx, x' \in Xx,x′∈X if f(x)=f(x′)f(x) = f(x')f(x)=f(x′) then x=x′x = x'x=x′.
The second one is more complicated.

Ralph Sarkis said:

If both !(f1,f2)=!(g1,g2)!(f_1,f_2) = {!}(g_1,g_2)!(f1​,f2​)=!(g1​,g2​), then !(g1,g2)!(g_1,g_2)!(g1​,g2​) makes the diagram above commute, so you can find what g1g_1g1​ and g2g_2g2​ are.

This hint was a great help for figuring out how to show that !!! is injective. Assume that !(f1,f2)=!(g1,g2)!(f_1,f_2) = !(g_1,g_2)!(f1​,f2​)=!(g1​,g2​). Then π1∘!(f1,f2)=f1\pi_1 \circ !(f_1,f_2) = f_1π1​∘!(f1​,f2​)=f1​, and similarly π1∘!(g1,g2)=g1\pi_1 \circ !(g_1,g_2) = g_1π1​∘!(g1​,g2​)=g1​, because of the diagram that is required to commute (see above). In addition, because !(f1,f2)=!(g1,g2)!(f_1,f_2) = !(g_1,g_2)!(f1​,f2​)=!(g1​,g2​), then π1∘!(f1,f2)=g1\pi_1 \circ !(f_1, f_2) = g_1π1​∘!(f1​,f2​)=g1​. So f1=g1f_1 = g_1f1​=g1​. Using π2\pi_2π2​, we can similarly show that f2=g2f_2 = g_2f2​=g2​. So if !(f1,f2)=!(g1,g2)!(f_1,f_2) = !(g_1,g_2)!(f1​,f2​)=!(g1​,g2​), then (f1,f2)=(g1,g2)(f_1, f_2) = (g_1,g_2)(f1​,f2​)=(g1​,g2​). We conclude that !!! is injective. We already saw that it is surjective, so it is bijective.
(deleted)

John Baez said:

The noble way is noble because it's a general fact about categories that "an isomorphism is a morphism with an inverse".

This does have its appeal! The simplicity you mention is also appealing.

It sounds fun to show that !!! is an isomorphism by finding an inverse for it. It will be interesting to see how that approach compares to showing !!! is injective and surjective.

We recall that !!! maps from C(X,A)×C(X,B)→C(X,Z)\mathsf{C}(X,A) \times \mathsf{C}(X,B) \to \mathsf{C}(X,Z)C(X,A)×C(X,B)→C(X,Z), where ZZZ together with π1\pi_1π1​ and π2\pi_2π2​ is a product of AAA and BBB. Let rrr be a proposed inverse, with r:C(X,Z)→C(X,A)×C(X,B)r: \mathsf{C}(X,Z) \to \mathsf{C}(X,A) \times \mathsf{C}(X,B)r:C(X,Z)→C(X,A)×C(X,B) acting by r(f)=(π1∘f,π2∘f)r(f) = (\pi_1 \circ f, \pi_2 \circ f)r(f)=(π1​∘f,π2​∘f) for each f∈C(X,Z)f \in \mathsf{C}(X,Z)f∈C(X,Z).

Computing (r∘!)(f1,f2)(r \circ !)(f_1, f_2)(r∘!)(f1​,f2​), we get (r∘!)(f1,f2)=r(!(f1,f2))=(π1∘!(f1,f2),π2∘!(f1,f2))(r \circ !)(f_1, f_2) = r(!(f_1, f_2)) = (\pi_1 \circ !(f_1, f_2), \pi_2 \circ !(f_1, f_2))(r∘!)(f1​,f2​)=r(!(f1​,f2​))=(π1​∘!(f1​,f2​),π2​∘!(f1​,f2​)). Because the diagram commutes, π1∘!(f1,f2)=f1\pi_1 \circ !(f_1, f_2) = f_1π1​∘!(f1​,f2​)=f1​ and π2∘!(f1,f2)=f2\pi_2 \circ !(f_1, f_2) = f_2π2​∘!(f1​,f2​)=f2​. So, we find that (r∘!)(f1,f2)=(f1,f2)(r \circ !)(f_1, f_2) = (f_1, f_2)(r∘!)(f1​,f2​)=(f1​,f2​) for each (f1,f2)(f_1, f_2)(f1​,f2​). That means r∘!r \circ !r∘! is the identity morphisms on C(X,A)×C(X,B)\mathsf{C}(X,A) \times \mathsf{C}(X,B)C(X,A)×C(X,B).

Computing (!∘r)(f)(! \circ r)(f)(!∘r)(f), we get (!∘r)(f)=!((π1∘f,π2∘f)) (! \circ r)(f)= !(( \pi_1 \circ f, \pi_2 \circ f))(!∘r)(f)=!((π1​∘f,π2​∘f)). We need a morphism in C(X,Z)\mathsf{C}(X,Z)C(X,Z) so that the diagram commutes with these morphisms to AAA and BBB. I think fff does it, so that (!∘r)(f)=f(! \circ r)(f) = f(!∘r)(f)=f. That means !∘r! \circ r!∘r is the identity morphisms on C(X,Z)\mathsf{C}(X,Z)C(X,Z).

So, rrr is an inverse of !!!, and so !!! is an isomorphism (and hence a bijection).

This more general approach felt easier, but it's hard to make a fair comparison when I'd warmed up by doing the other method first. :upside_down: I do like how this approach uses an argument pattern that is less specific to Set\mathsf{Set}Set, though!

Great! Actually, after further thought, this is how I'd try to make everything as simple as possible. The product A×BA \times BA×B comes with projections

π1:A×B→A\pi_1 : A \times B \to Aπ1​:A×B→A

and

π2:A×B→B\pi_2: A \times B \to Bπ2​:A×B→B

so any morphism

f:X→A×Bf: X \to A \times Bf:X→A×B

gives a pair of morphisms

π1∘f:X→A,π2∘f:X→B\pi_1 \circ f : X \to A, \quad \pi_2 \circ f : X \to Bπ1​∘f:X→A,π2​∘f:X→B

I have just described a map

C(X,A×B)→C(X,A)×C(X,B)\mathsf{C}(X, A \times B) \to \mathsf{C}(X, A) \times \mathsf{C}(X, B)C(X,A×B)→C(X,A)×C(X,B)

sending fff to the pair (π1∘f,π2∘f)(\pi_1 \circ f, \pi_2 \circ f)(π1​∘f,π2​∘f).

Now: the universal property of the product says this map is a bijection.

That is - saying the exact same thing more slowly - given any pair of maps f1:X→A,f2:X→Bf_1 : X \to A, f_2: X \to Bf1​:X→A,f2​:X→B, there exists a unique f:X→A×Bf: X \to A \times Bf:X→A×B such that

f1=π1∘f,f2=π2∘f f_1 = \pi_1 \circ f, \quad f_2 = \pi_2 \circ ff1​=π1​∘f,f2​=π2​∘f

So, this bijectiveness of the map

C(X,A×B)→C(X,A)×C(X,B)\mathsf{C}(X, A \times B) \to \mathsf{C}(X, A) \times \mathsf{C}(X, B)C(X,A×B)→C(X,A)×C(X,B)

that I described is the universal property of the product!

John Baez said:

So, this bijectiveness of the map

C(X,A×B)→C(X,A)×C(X,B)\mathsf{C}(X, A \times B) \to \mathsf{C}(X, A) \times \mathsf{C}(X, B)C(X,A×B)→C(X,A)×C(X,B)

that I described is the universal property of the product!

Oh, that is a nice way to put it! It is interesting that the injectivity and surjectivity become easier to see from the product diagram when we work with the inverse of !!!.

Yeah, I think it's important that the inverse of the map you're calling !, not ! itself, is the really obvious map.

This is a general fact about limits and colimits: the universal property says that some "obvious map" has an inverse.
